case_name: Gurusidhwaswami v. Dakshina Maharashtra Digambar Jain Sabha

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 187 of 1952 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 187 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal from Bombay High Court judgment dated October 19, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 19th day of October, 1949, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay  Bavdekar and Dixit JJ.

facts.text: Bombay High Court affirmed Civil Judge Hubli decree dated December 17, 1945 in Special Civil Suit No. 21 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: in Appeal from Original Decree No. 275 of 1946 arising out of the Judgment and Decree dated the 17th day of December, 1945, in Special Civil Suit No. 21 of 1944 of the Court of Civil Judge  Senior Division , Hubli.

facts.text: Plaintiff is the spiritual head or Mathadhipati of Murusavirmath in Hubli Taluka, Dharwar district.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff appellant is the spiritual bead or Mathadhipati of a Lingayet Math known as Murusavirmath situated within Hubli Taluka in the district of Dharwar.

facts.text: On November 13, 1887, Gurusidhwaswami granted permanent lease of land in R. No. 34 to Pradhanappa at rent Rs. 50 per annum for first six years then Rs. 25 annually.

anchor.surface_text: On November 13, 1887, Gurusidhwaswami, who was the then head of this religious institution, granted a permanent lease of a tract of land belonging to the Math and forming part of R. No. 34, in favour of one Pradhanappa and the rent agreed to be paid by the lessee was Rs. 50 per annum for the first six years and thereafter at the rate of Rs. 25 annually.

facts.text: On June 19, 1892, Pradhanappa sold portion of leasehold (Schedule 1b to plaint) to Bharamappa.

anchor.surface_text: On June 19,1892, Pradhanappa sold a portion of the lease hold property, which is described in Schedule 1 b  to the plaint, to a person named Bharamappa.

facts.text: In 1897 Gurusidhwaswami died and was succeeded by Gangadhar Swami who accepted rents without repudiating the lease.

anchor.surface_text: In 1897 Gurusidhwaswami died and was succeeded by his disciple Gangadhar Swami who did number repudiate the permanent lease granted by his predecessor and went on accepting rents from the lessee in the same way as before.

facts.text: In April 1905, Schedule 1a land sold in execution against Pradhanappa's heirs to Kadayya, who sold it to Bharamappa.

anchor.surface_text: In April, 1905, another part of the land, which is described in Schedule 1 a  to the plaint, was put up for sale in execution of a decree against Pradhanappas heirs and it was purchased by one Kadayya, and Kadayya in his turn sold the same to Bharamappa who had already purchased Schedule 1 b  plot by private purchase.

facts.text: On April 8, 1910, Bharamappa gifted plots 1a and 1b to Dakshina Maharashtra Digambar Jain Sabha for building a school for Jain students.

anchor.surface_text: On April 8, 1910, Bharamappa made a gift of the entire premises companysisting of plots 1 a  and 1 b  to the Dakshina Maharashtra Digambar Jain Sabha, a registered body, for the purpose of building a school upon it for the education of Jain students.

facts.text: On August 31, 1920, Gangadhar Swami died.

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1920, Gangadhar Swami died and for some time after his death the affairs of the Math were in the hands of a companymittee of management.

facts.text: On November 25, 1925, present plaintiff Gurusidhwaswami became head of the Math.

anchor.surface_text: On November 25, 1925, the present plaintiff Gurusidhwaswami became the head of the Math.

facts.text: On August 27, 1932, plaintiff instituted Suit No. 80 of 1932 against heirs of Bharamappa for possession, alleging lease invalid without legal necessity.

anchor.surface_text: On August 27, 1932, the plaintiff instituted a suit, being Suit No. 80 of 1932, against the heirs and successors of Bharamappa for recovery of possession of the land companyprised in the permanent lease on the allegation that there being numberlegal necessity for granting the lease, the alienation was number binding on the Math and became void on the death of the last Mahant.

facts.text: Jain Sabha was defendant No. 23 in 1932 suit under wrong name.

anchor.surface_text: The Jain Sabha was impleaded as defendant No. 23 in the suit, but under a wrong name.

facts.text: 1932 suit dismissed by trial judge, reversed by Bombay High Court on November 26, 1942, allowing possession except against defendant 23 (Jain Sabha) due to misdescription.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the trial judge but on appeal by the plaintiff to the High Court of Bombay, the trial companyrts judgment was reversed and the plaintiffs claim for khas possession was allowed in respect of the suit land against all the defendants with the exception of defendant No. 23 who was dismissed from the suit on the ground of misdescription. The judgment of the High Court is dated the 26th of November, 1942.

facts.text: On December 3, 1943, plaintiff commenced present suit against respondent Jain Sabha for possession.

anchor.surface_text: On 3rd December, 1943, the plaintiff appellant companymenced the present suit against the respondent Jain Sabha claiming khas possession of the land gifted in its favour by Bharamappa, alleging that as the original permanent lease was number binding on the Math for number being supported by legal necessity, the defendant companyld number acquire any title by grant from the successor of the lessee.

facts.text: Trial court held original lease not supported by legal necessity but suit barred by limitation under Article 134-B Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The trial judge decided the first point in favour of the plaintiff, but on the question of limitation the decision was adverse to him. The result was that the plaintiffs suit was dismissed Thereupon the plaintiff took an appeal to the High Court of Bombay and the learned Judges, who heard the appeal, companycurred in the decision of the companyrt below and dismissed the appeal and the suit.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed appeal, holding suit governed by Article 134-B, 12 years from previous Mahant's death in 1920.

anchor.surface_text: Both the companyrts below have held that a suit of this description is governed by article 134-B of the Limitation Act and the period of limitation is 12 years companyputed from the date when the previous Mahant died. The plaintiffs predecessor admittedly died in 1920 and the suit was brought more than 12 years after that and hence it was time-barred.

facts.text: Plaintiff's predecessor died in 1920.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs predecessor admittedly died in 1920 and the suit was brought more than 12 years after that and hence it was time-barred.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered October 14, 1953 by Mukherjea J.

anchor.surface_text: R. Madhavi  K. R. Bengeri, with him  for the respondent, 1953. October 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUKHERJEA J.-This appeal is directed against a judgment and decree of a Division Bench of the Bombay High Court dated October 19, 1949,

facts.text: Document by Bharamappa to Jain Sabha is a deed of gift, not sub-lease.

anchor.surface_text: We have gone carefully through the document executed by Bharamappa in, favour of the Jain Sabha. Both in form and in substance it is a deed of gift and number a sub-lease.

facts.text: Gift deed provided land reverts if school removed or ceases.

anchor.surface_text: The gift, it seems, Was made for a specific purpose, namely, for companystruction of a school building upon the site which was to be used for the education of the boys and girls of the Jain companymunity, and it was for this reason that the deed provided that on the companytingency of the school being removed from the site or its ceasing to exist, the land would revert to the donor.

facts.text: Lease was for valuable consideration.

anchor.surface_text: It may be taken that the word assign is sufficiently wide to companyer a lessee as well but the difficulty is, that as the lease was for valuable companysideration, the case would companye within the terms of the exception laid down in section 10

facts.text: Gangadhar Swami consented to lessee continuing in possession after 1897.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the immediate successor of the alienating Mahant companysented to the lessees companytinuing in possession of the property and thereby he might be treated as creating an interest in the lessee companymensurate with the period of his lifetime or the tenure of his office.

facts.text: Plaintiff did not accept rent or treat lease as subsisting after Gangadhar's death.

anchor.surface_text: After his death, however, his successor did number accept any rent from the lessee or otherwise treated the lease as subsisting and in 1932 he brought the suit for recovery of possession of the property against the successors of the original lessee

The plaintiffs predecessor admittedly died in 1920 and the suit was brought more than 12 years after that and hence it was time-barred.

anchor.surface_text: To get round the plea of limitation, the learned Attorney-General, who appeared in support of the appeal, has put forward a two-fold contention. It is argued in the first place that the decree for ejectment, which was passed in favour of the plaintiff and against the heirs of Bharamappa in the earlier suit of 1932, was binding on the present defendant on the principle that a decree against a lessee binds the sub-lessee as well.

arguments.claim: Document to Jain Sabha is deed of gift, not sub-lease

anchor.surface_text: We have gone carefully through the document executed by Bharamappa in favour of the Jain Sabha. Both in form and in substance it is a deed of gift and not a sub-lease.

holdings.text: The suit of 1932 was not a suit by a landlord against his tenant but a suit by the holder or manager of the Math to recover possession of Math property improperly alienated by his predecessor on the ground that the defendants became trespassers.

anchor.surface_text: This was not a suit by a landlord against his tenant it was a suit by the holder or manager of the Math to recover possession of Math property which was improperly alienated by his predecessor on the ground that the defendant became a trespasser as soon as the previous Mahant died and the plaintiff was entitled to recover possession on proof of his title.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease valid only during alienating Mahant's life; successor repudiated by suing for possession on title without accepting rent, treating defendants as trespassers after his predecessor's death.

holdings.text: The alienation by the Mahant without legal necessity was binding only during his lifetime; successor's consent created lessee interest only coterminous with successor's tenure.

anchor.surface_text: The Mahant, who created the permanent lease in 1887, might not have been able to derogate from his grant and the lease might be taken to be valid so long as the alienating Mahant lived. As soon as he died, it was open to his successor to repudiate the lease and recover possession of the property on the ground that the alienation was not binding on the endowment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied doctrine of mathadhipati alienations: valid during incumbency absent necessity; Gangadhar's acceptance bound only for his life; present plaintiff repudiated.

holdings.text: The document executed by Bharamappa in favour of the Jain Sabha is a deed of gift and not a sub-lease.

anchor.surface_text: We have gone carefully through the document executed by Bharamappa in favour of the Jain Sabha. Both in form and in substance it is a deed of gift and not a sub-lease.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Careful examination of document form and substance; specific purpose gift with reverter condition does not convert to sub-lease.

holdings.text: Attaching a condition of reverter to the deed of gift does not convert it into a sub-lease.

anchor.surface_text: The gift, it seems, Was made for a specific purpose... and it was for this reason that the deed provided that on the contingency of the school being removed from the site or its ceasing to exist, the land would revert to the donor. The attaching of a condition like that to a deed of gift could not, in our opinion, convert it into a sublease.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Condition for specific purpose (school ceasing) is valid in gift deeds; does not imply lease relationship or rent obligation.

holdings.text: Even if the 1932 decree bound the defendant, the present suit would be barred under section 47 CPC, though court could treat it as execution proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: even if the appellants contention is right, the present suit would be barred under section 47 of the Civil Procedure Code and the proper remedy of the plaintiff would be to apply for execution of the decree in the previous suit. This difficulty, however, is not insuperable, as under section 47...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar under s.47, but convertible absent limitation/jurisdiction issues; obiter as merits fail.

holdings.text: Section 10 of the Limitation Act does not apply as the original lease was for valuable consideration, bringing the case within the exception.

anchor.surface_text: It may be taken that the word assign is sufficiently wide to cover a lessee as well but the difficulty is, that as the lease was for valuable consideration, the case would come within the terms of the exception laid down in section 10

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lessee qualifies as 'assign'; exception excludes those taking for valuable consideration from s.10 benefit.

holdings.text: The expression 'valuable consideration' has a well-known connotation in law distinct from 'adequate consideration'; nominal rent suffices.

anchor.surface_text: We desire to point out that the expression valuable consideration has a well known connotation in law and it is not synonymous with adequate consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected argument that low rent (Rs.50/25) is nominal hence inadequate; legal term means any consideration of value.

holdings.text: The suit is barred by limitation under Article 134-B of the Limitation Act, period of 12 years from death of previous Mahant in 1920.

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts below have held that a suit of this description is governed by article 134-B of the Limitation Act and the period of limitation is 12 years computed from the date when the previous Mahant died. The plaintiffs predecessor admittedly died in 1920 and the suit was brought more than 12 years after that and hence it was time-barred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmed lower courts; rejected petitioner's two-fold contentions to avoid limitation (1932 decree and s.10).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the first companytention of the AttorneyGeneral must fail. As regards the other ground raised by the Attorney- General, we are of opinion that the point is without any substance, and section 10 of the Indian Limitation Act is of numberassistance to the plaintiff in the present it case. In order that a suit may have the benefit of section 10, it must be a suit against a person in whom the property has become vested in trust for any specific purpose or against his legal representatives or assigns, number being assigns for valuable companysideration.

outcome.relief_summary: Plaintiff's suit for khas possession dismissed as barred by limitation under article 134-B; previous decree does not bind defendant as not sub-lessee; section 10 Limitation Act inapplicable as transfer for valuable consideration

anchor.surface_text: This was not a suit by a landlord against his tenant it was a suit by the holder or manager of the Math to recover possession of Math property which was improperly alienated by his predecessor on the ground that the defendant became a trespasser as soon as the previous Mahant died and the plaintiff was entitled to recover possession on proof of his title.

In our opinion, the first companytention of the AttorneyGeneral must fail. As regards the other ground raised by the Attorney- General, we are of opinion that the point is without any substance, and section 10 of the Indian Limitation Act is of numberassistance to the plaintiff in the present it case. In order that a suit may have the benefit of section 10, it must be a suit against a person in whom the property has become vested in trust for any specific purpose or against his legal representatives or assigns, number being assigns for valuable companysideration.

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts below have held that a suit of this description is governed by article 134-B of the Limitation Act and the period of limitation is 12 years computed from the date when the previous Mahant died. The plaintiffs predecessor admittedly died in 1920 and the suit was brought more than 12 years after that and hence it was time-barred.

In our opinion, the first companytention of the AttorneyGeneral must fail. As regards the other ground raised by the Attorney- General, we are of opinion that the point is without any substance, and section 10 of the Indian Limitation Act is of numberassistance to the plaintiff in the present it case.
